legislation.statute: The Iowa Renewable Energy Law is a capacity-based standard, which requires its investor-owned utilities to own or contract a total of 105 MW of renewable energy. It is split between MidAmerican Energy (55.2 MW, 52.57% of demand) and Alliant Energy Interstate Power and Light (49.8 MW., 47.43% of demand). There are no mandated increases, and the target has already been achieved.

rps_tech_details.name: Eligible Technologies
rps_tech_details.description: Solar, Wind, Waste management, Resource recovery, Refuse-derived fuel, Agricultural crops or residues, Wood-burning facilities, or Small hydropower facilities

rps_tech_details.name: Technology Requirements
rps_tech_details.description: None (voluntary goal of 1,000 MW wind by 2010)

overview: Two separate state RPS schedules (primary and secondary)
snapshot.policy_trajectory: Iowa's REL does not define a 'ramp-up', because the nature of the goal is a specific capacity to be achieved.
snapshot.summary: Iowa's Alternative Energy Law (REL) establishes a minimum amount of renewable energy that must be purchased by the state's electricity providers. This page identifies and describes the features of the RPS and how they work together to define the minimum amount of renewable energy that will be sold in Iowa.
